properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values will reach near -40 beginning overnight tonight. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and ice pellet accumulations are expected. Total amounts: 15 to 30 cm. Locations: western, central, and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday evening into Wednesday. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin Tuesday evening, and then change to ice pellets later Tuesday night, before changing back to snow on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets, and an extended period of freezing rain are expected on Tuesday. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 20 cm. Location: south central New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Remarks: snow will begin Tuesday morning, transition through a period of ice pellets, and then change to freezing rain by Tuesday afternoon or early Tuesday evening before ending Wednesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold will continue into Tuesday morning. What: Temperatures of minus 32 to 37; wind chills of minus 40 to 44. Where: Northwestern Ontario and parts of North of Superior When: During the evening, overnight, and early morning hours. Extreme cold is forecast to improve by Tuesday afternoon, at which time temperatures will moderate somewhat. Actions: ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. An extended period of freezing rain is expected. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday near noon until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow Tuesday morning, and then transition through a period of ice pellets and then freezing rain by Tuesday afternoon before ending Wednesday morning. Along the Fundy Coast freezing rain will be mixed with, or change to, rain during the afternoon or early Tuesday evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow are expected. Winter storm tonight into Tuesday morning giving 20 to 30 cm of snow. Heavy snow is expected to develop over the entire region this evening and persist into Tuesday morning where 20 to 25 centimetres of snow is expected. Northeast winds gusting near 50 km/h will result in very poor visibility in blowing snow especially from midnight to midday Tuesday. Even higher amounts of snow, about 30 centimetres, are possible in some locations. Travel will be extremely hazardous until the snow moves east of the region on Tuesday morning. Local blowing snow may persist until Tuesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. Winter storm tonight into Tuesday morning giving 25 to 35 cm of snow. Heavy snow is expected to develop over the entire region this evening and persist into Tuesday morning where at least 25 centimetres of snow is expected. Northeast winds gusting near 50 km/h will result in very poor visibility in blowing snow especially from midnight to Tuesday afternoon. Even higher amounts of snow may be possible, up to 40 centimetres, in some locations due to extra moisture coming off Lake Ontario. Locally higher amounts may also occur on the higher elevations of the escarpment. Travel will be extremely hazardous until the snow moves east of the region on Tuesday morning. Local blowing snow may persist until Tuesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T11:25:10-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba. Extreme cold values of -40 to -45 are again expected to spread across parts of southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba this evening. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold windchill values of -55 are expected overnight tonight. Temperatures are expected to moderate on Tuesday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T17:13:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T01:14:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0429286489.2021
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Precipitation changing from snow to freezing rain. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: 15 cm. Locations: Prince County. Time Span: Tuesday morning to Tuesday night. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will spread across Northumberland Strait early Tuesday, and will change over to ice pellets then freezing rain later in the day. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T12:05:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T20:06:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0916312682.2021
Area: Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Prolonged periods of freezing rain. Locations: Queens and Kings County. Time Span: Tuesday afternoon to Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will spread across the province early Tuesday, and will change over to ice pellets, then freezing rain, and then to rain over central and eastern portions of the province by Tuesday evening. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T12:01:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T20:02:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3780761523.2021
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Heavy snow is expected to move into the area overnight and persist into Tuesday with snowfall accumulations of 15 to 20 cm, possibly reaching 25 cm in some places. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T13:27:19-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow will continue this afternoon and tonight in the wake of a low pressure system. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Time span: near midnight Tuesday night. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm (highest amounts over extreme southern areas). Time span: overnight Tuesday into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain will change to rain Tuesday night and taper to showers Wednesday morning. Significant snowmelt and runoff are likely to occur. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-16T11:24:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T19:25:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0379896411.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. Winter storm tonight into Tuesday giving 25 to 35 cm of snow. Heavy snow is expected to develop over the entire region late this evening and persist into Tuesday morning where at least 25 centimetres of snow is expected. Northeast winds gusting near 50 km/h will result in very poor visibility in blowing snow especially from midnight to Tuesday afternoon. Blowing snow is also possible early Tuesday afternoon when the winds become more westerly. Travel will be extremely hazardous until the snow moves east of the region on Tuesday afternoon. Local blowing snow may persist until late Tuesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T12:19:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T20:20:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0558577286.2021

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba. Extreme cold values of -40 to -45 are again expected to spread across parts of southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba this evening. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T13:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T21:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1945360960.2021

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. A prolonged period of freezing rain is expected for Tuesday. Locations: Nova Scotia Time Span: Tuesday morning through to Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will develop across the province early Tuesday, will transition to freezing rain, and then will change again to rain from west to east throughout the day. The greatest impacts from the freezing rain will be over inland areas and in northern portions of the province. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-16T11:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T20:00:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3716844736.2021

Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
